patients.title: P.L.
patients.summary:
• 61 years of age
  • Recurrence ≤12 months postadjuvant therapy
  • Liver metastases
  • Mild/moderate symptoms
patients.banner:
25.8% of CONFIRM† patients had liver
metastases at baseline.1,‡

row: Woman aged 61 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 7 months ago
Patient presents with moderate fatigue and mild right abdominal pain
Physical examination reveals right upper quadrant (RUQ) tenderness
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1

imaging.row: Bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans show three 1- to 2-cm masses in liver (1 in left hepatic lobe, 2 in right hepatic lobe)

row: Liver mass biopsy confirms metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Hemoglobin: 11.5 mg/dL
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 175 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1390903. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

Di Leo A, Jerusalem G, Petruzelka L, et al. Results of the CONFIRM phase III trial comparing fulvestrant
250 mg with fulvestrant 500 mg in postmenopausal women with estrogen receptor–positive advanced
breast cancer. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(30):4594-4600.

patients.title: M.K.
patients.banner:
25.8% of CONFIRM† patients had liver
metastases at baseline.1,‡
patients.summary:
• 72 years of age
  • Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant therapy
  • Liver metastases
  • Asymptomatic

row: Woman aged 72 years with a history of breast cancer and osteoporosis
Patient fell; chest radiograph ordered to rule out rib fracture
Radiograph revealed few ill-defined lesions in the lung 3 years after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)
Workup for metastatic disease revealed liver masses, which were confirmed to be malignant
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 4 months later
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 2
Computed tomography (CT) scan reveals 2 liver masses and lung lesions consistent with benign calcified granulomas
Bone scan/positron emission tomography(PET) scan is negative for metastatic disease in bone
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Liver mass biopsy confirms estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal
growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status, with
pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 73 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1390903. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

Di Leo A, Jerusalem G, Petruzelka L, et al. Results of the CONFIRM phase III trial comparing fulvestrant
250 mg with fulvestrant 500 mg in postmenopausal women with estrogen receptor–positive advanced
breast cancer. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(30):4594-4600.

row: Woman 66 years of age with a history of breast cancer

Patient completed adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT)
(tamoxifen) 13 months ago

Diagnosed with pneumonia; showed clinical improvement; infiltrate cleared on x-ray, but there were persistent bilateral nodules
  • Biopsy of lung nodule confirmed metastases
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 5 months later
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Chest x-ray reveals suspicious bilateral 1- to 2-cm nodules
Chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and bone scan indicate lung nodules with no other sites of disease
Biopsy of lung nodule confirms estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 57 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1

row: Asymptomatic woman aged 72 years with a history of breast cancer completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 9 months ago

Bone metastases (femur) found
  • Patient falls off bicycle and fractures left femur. During surgical repair (open reduction and internal fixation) of femur, fracture is discovered to be pathologic
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Radionuclide bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), chest x-ray, and chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans show mixed osteolytic and osteoblastic lesions in left femur
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Biopsy of bone tissue confirms metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status, with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 82 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1196503. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

patients.summary:

row: Woman aged 61 years with a history of breast cancer presents with back pain 14 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)
Lumbar spine magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed metastases
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 4 months later
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Bone scan reveals abnormal uptake in lumbar spine and ribs
Chest x-ray and chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans reveal diffuse metastases in lumbar spine and ribs with no signs of any impending pathologic fractures
MRI of spine confirms findings of CT and indicates that impending cord compression is unlikely
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Needle aspiration biopsy of rib confirms abnormality. Estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 78 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1196503. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

Di Leo A, Jerusalem G, Petruzelka L, et al. Results of the CONFIRM phase III trial comparing fulvestrant
250 mg with fulvestrant 500 mg in postmenopausal women with estrogen receptor–positive advanced
breast cancer. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(30):4594-4600.

row: Woman aged 68 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 7 months ago
Patient is on a statin for hypercholesterolemia
On a routine follow-up visit, her alkaline phosphatase was noted to be elevated and a workup was ordered
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Ultrasound of liver shows 2 masses, each approximately 2 cm

Bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), chest x-ray, and chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans reveal 4 nodules in left lung, varying in size between 1.6 and
3.0 cm, and the 2 masses in liver
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Liver mass and lung nodule biopsies confirm metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 192 U/mL
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase
  • Other liver function tests normal
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1

patients.summary:
• 58 years of age

row: 58-year-old patient with a history of breast cancer
Patient had completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)

At 20 months after completion of therapy, patient presented with mild/moderate cough (cough from nasopharyngitis,
which later resolved)

Chest scan showed small lung nodule (0.3 cm) in the right central lung
  • Lung cancer metastases confirmed via biopsy
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 10 months later
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Bone scan, chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans, and chest x-rays are performed
Imaging reveals 1 nodule (0.8 cm) in the right central lung; solitary, 1.2-cm nodule in left lung; 1 mass (1.1 cm) in liver
Biopsy of the liver mass confirms estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status, with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 75 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.3
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1196503. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

Di Leo A, Jerusalem G, Petruzelka L, et al. Results of the CONFIRM phase III trial comparing fulvestrant
250 mg with fulvestrant 500 mg in postmenopausal women with estrogen receptor–positive advanced
breast cancer. J Clin Oncol. 2010;28(30):4594-4600.
Data on File, 1390903. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

patients.summary:
• 67 years of age
  • Recurrence ≤12 months postadjuvant therapy
  • Liver and bone metastases
  • Asymptomatic

row: Woman aged 67 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 8.5 months ago
Patient is taking a statin for hypercholesterolemia
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0

Bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans, and
x-rays are performed
CT scan shows 3 distinct, 1- to 2-cm masses in the right lobe of the liver
X-rays reveal several small lucencies in the skull and right femur; bone scan shows several areas of uptake in skull and femur

Biopsy of the liver masses confirms metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status
with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Results of routine evaluation show abnormal liver function tests thought to be due to statin therapy
    • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 190 IU/L
    • Aspartate transaminase (AST): 75 IU/L
    • Alanine transaminase (ALT): 81 IU/L
    • Bilirubin: 0.9 mg/dL
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 58 U/mL
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.3
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1196503. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

row: Woman aged 64 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient presents with pain in the lumbar spine 10 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans are performed
Bone scan reveals 3 areas of abnormal uptake in the lumbar spine. Lumbar MRI reveals lytic/blastic lesions in the lumbar spine with no compression fracture or impending cord impingement
CT scan and liver MRI reveal a solitary 1.5-cm mass in right hepatic lobe; no evidence of biliary dilatation
Liver aspiration confirms estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with the primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 65 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.3
<sup>§</sup>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
Data on File, 1196503. AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP.

row: Woman aged 64 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 15 months ago
Patient was a smoker with a 50 pack/year history

Patient was found to have an abnormality on a chest radiograph performed as part of a routine employment
physical
  • Subsequent chest x-ray and computed tomography (CT)
    scan revealed a pleural effusion one-third of the way up
    the left hemithorax and 2 small nodules in the right
    upper lung (each 1.2 cm)§
  • Biopsy of lung nodule confirmed metastases
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 8 months later
ECOG<sup>||</sup> Performance Status: 0
Bone scan, brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and CT scans of the pelvis and abdomen are performed
Bone scan reveals uptake in L1, L3, and L4

Thoracentesis:
  • Cytology shows malignant cells with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status

Laboratory values:
  • Routine chemistries are normal
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 74 U/mL

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.3

  • Recurrence ≤12 months postadjuvant therapy
  • Liver and skin metastases

row: Woman aged 62 years with a history of breast cancer and rheumatoid arthritis

Patient presents with a 1.5-cm metastasis in skin overlying lumpectomy site detected during routine clinical examination 11 months after completion of 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Ultrasound reveals two 1.0-cm metastases in liver
Bone scan, chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirm liver findings; no other sites of metastatic disease detected<sup>||</sup>
Brain MRI negative
Biopsies of liver and skin confirm estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Alkaline phosphatase levels slightly elevated: 190 IU/L
  • Other liver function tests normal
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 260 U/mL
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA): 5.5 ng/mL
*Recurrence during or within 12 months of completing adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen).

counted only once in that site.3

patients.title: L.C.
patients.banner:
10.9% of CONFIRM† patients had pleura
metastases at baseline.1,‡
patients.summary:
• 51 years of age
  • Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant therapy
  • Pleural effusion
  • Mild/moderate symptoms

row: Woman aged 51 years with a history of breast cancer

Patient presented with mild shortness of breath 24 months
after completion of 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen)

Clinical examination revealed dullness to percussion in right lower lung field
  • Workup including chest x-ray and thoracentesis confirmed pleural metastases
Patient admitted to difficulty remembering to take pills
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 4 months later
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Chest x-ray shows small pleural effusion on right side<sup>||</sup>
Chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans are negative, except for a moderate volume pleural effusion on right side
Bone scan and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) are negative

Thoracentesis:
  • Cytology shows malignant cells
  • Estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 47 U/mL

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

‡Total number of patients=736. Patients with multiple lesions in the same site are
counted only once in that site.1

lymph node metastases at baseline.1,‡

  • Asymptomatic

row: Asymptomatic woman aged 57 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 22 months ago

Distant metastatic lymph node found
  • During routine clinical exam, a palpable 1.6-cm cervical lymph node is discovered; fine-needle aspiration in office confirmed metastatic breast cancer

Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 6 months later
based on surveillance scan
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Neck/chest/abdominal/pelvic computed tomography (CT) scan confirms a 2.5-cm cervical lymph node; bone scan is normal<sup>||</sup>
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Biopsy of the cervical lymph node confirms metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 53 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

counted only once in that site.1

row: Woman aged 54 years with a history of breast cancer
Patient completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 11 months ago
Patient presents with a 1.2-cm mass in the ipsilateral breast found during a routine mammogram and confirmed by breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Bone scan, brain MRI, and computed tomography (CT) scans of the chest, pelvis, and abdomen are performed
CT scan of the chest reveals a small volume pleural effusion on the left side<sup>||</sup>
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Biopsy of breast mass confirms metastatic disease with
estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human
epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status
with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Thoracentesis:
  • Cytology shows malignant cells with ER+/PgR+, HER2- status

Laboratory values:
  • Routine chemistries are normal
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 44 U/mL

skin/soft-tissue metastases at baseline.1,‡
patients.summary:
• 60 years of age
  • Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant therapy
  • Skin/soft tissue and pleura metastases
  • Asymptomatic

row: Asymptomatic woman aged 60 years with a history of breast cancer treated with a left mastectomy
Completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 25 months ago
Skin and soft-tissue metastases found

During routine clinical exam, 2 separate 0.5-cm nodules in the mastectomy scar tissue and a solitary 1.2-cm nodule in the skin of the left upper abdominal quadrant are detected; biopsy shows metastatic breast cancer
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 6 months later with identical, multiple skin lesions seen on abdomen
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
Chest/abdominal/pelvic computed tomography (CT) scans and bone scan reveal a new, small-volume right pleural effusion<sup>||</sup>
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Thoracentesis shows malignant cells and cell block shows metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status; pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 40 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.
†COmparisoN of FASLODEX In Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.2

row: Woman aged 70 years with a history of breast cancer
Completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 20 months ago

Woman fell resulting in evaluation of a bruised right hip; imaging showed 2 small lytic lesions to right hip
  • Bone metastases confirmed via bone scan and biopsy

Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 6 months later
based on surveillance scan
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 0
X-ray image of pelvic area reveals 3 small lytic lesions to right hip
Chest/pelvic/abdominal computed tomography (CT) scans and bone scan confirm pelvic bone lesions, which are consistent with metastatic disease; no evidence of other metastatic disease

Biopsy of bone tissue confirms metastatic disease with estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status; pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 84 U/mL
  • Normal liver function tests

*Recurrence >12 months after completion of adjuvant hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and progression
after hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) for advanced disease.

row: Woman aged 71 years with a history of breast cancer

row: 73-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer
Patient had completed 5 years of adjuvant hormonal therapy (HT) (tamoxifen) 16 months ago

Presented with localized, non-radiating pain in center of
chest; tenderness on palpation over sternum, normal electrocardiography (EKG)
Bone scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) suggested metastatic disease localized to sternum with 1 lytic lesion
Tamoxifen started and patient progressed 14 months later and experienced a return of chest pain
Patient had prior radiation to chest
ECOG<sup>§</sup> Performance Status: 1
Bone scan and MRI reveal increase in size of lytic lesion in sternum compared to scan 6 months prior
No evidence of other metastatic disease

Bone biopsy confirms metastatic disease. Estrogen receptor (ER)+/progesterone receptor (PgR)+, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) negative status, with pathology consistent with primary tumor

Laboratory values:
  • Elevated cancer antigen CA 27.29: 81 U/mL
